item.label: Cerebrum, Lobes
item.name: Lobes
item.description: Each cerebral hemisphere consists of lobes:  frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal.  In some instances a limbic lobe is designated-- consisting of a portion of the medial aspect of the other lobes.

item.label: Frontal lobe
item.name: Frontal lobe
item.description: The frontal lobe is the most anterior lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. It includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, supplementary motor cortex, frontal eye fields, prefrontal cortex and orbital cortex. Via connections with the dorsomedial nucleus of thalamus and elsewhere, it is associated with the limbic system.

item.label: Parietal lobe
item.name: Parietal lobe
item.description: The parietal lobe is the most centrally located lobe of the cerebral hemisphere, bounded by the frontal, occipital and temporal lobes. The parietal lobe is noted for functionally important areas: the post-central gyrus is primary somatosensory cortex, the inferior parietal lobule is important for language comprehension and areas of association cortex are involved with complex aspects of spatial orientation and perception.

item.label: Occipital lobe
item.name: Occipital lobe
item.description: The occipital lobe is the most posterior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres. It is clinically important because it includes the primary and association visual cortex.

item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Precentral
item.name: Precentral gyrus
item.description: The precental gyrus is a vertically-oriented gyrus of the cerebral hemisphere located immediately anterior to the central sulcus. Functionally, it serves as the primary motor cortex. The body and head are represented somatotopically within the gyrus such that the head is located laterally near the lateral sulcus and the feet are located most medially in the longitudinal fissure. In Brodmann's designation, this gyrus is termed Area 4.

item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Postcentral
item.name: Postcentral gyrus
item.description: The postcentral gyrus is the vertically-oriented gyrus of the cerebral hemisphere located immediately posterior to the central sulcus. Functionally, it serves as the primary somatic sensory cortex. The body and head are represented somatotopically within the gyrus such that the head is located laterally near the lateral sulcus and the feet are located most medially in the longitudinal fissure. In Brodmann's designation, this gyrus is termed Areas 3,1,2.

item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Cingulate
item.name: Cingulate gyrus
item.description: The cingulate gyrus is the region of the cerebral cortex that arcs above the corpus callosum on the medial aspect of the hemisphere. Along with the parahippocampal gyrus to which it is connected by the isthmus of the cingulate gyrus, posterior to the splenium of the corpus callosum, it is considered to be the "Limbic lobe" of the brain.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Central
item.name: Central sulcus
item.description: The central sulcus (of Rolando) is an important sulcus on the lateral aspect of the cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal from the parietal lobes. It extends from just medial to the superior border of the hemisphere downward to the lateral or Sylvian fissure. The primary motor and somatosensory areas of cortex form the gyri (pre-central and post-central, respectively) on either side of this sulcus.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Cingulate
item.name: Cingulate sulcus
item.description: The cingulate sulcus curves over and immediately dorsal to the cingulate gyrus on the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere. Posteriorly, a marginal branch extends toward the superior surface of parietal lobe, demarcating the posterior boundary of the paracentral lobule.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Marginal
item.name: Marginal branch
item.description: The marginal sulcus is the portion of the cingulate sulcus that separates the paracentral lobule from the precuneus.  It is AKA the marginal branch of the cingulate sulcus.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Callosal
item.name: Callosal sulcus
item.description: The callosal sulcus is located directly above the corpus callosum.  It is best seen on a hemisected specimen.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Calcarine
item.name: Calcarine sulcus
item.description: The calcarine fissure or sulcus is AKA as Area 17 of Brodmann. It is a prominent sulcus on the medial surface of the occipital lobe consisting of an upper bank (cuneus) and lower bank (lingual gyrus) where the neurons of the primary visual cortex are located.

item.label: Cerebral sulcus, Parieto-occipital
item.name: Parietooccipital fissure
item.description: The parieto-occipital sulcus is a deep fissure that divides the parietal from the occipital lobes on the medial aspect of the cerebral hemisphere.

item.label: Commissure, Anterior
item.name: Anterior commissure
item.description: The anterior commissure is a small and compact bundle of commissural axons located just beneath and caudal to the rostrum of the corpus callosum. It connects corresponding areas in the temporal cortices as well as olfactory structures.

item.label: Commissure, Corpus callosum
item.name: Corpus callosum
item.description: The corpus callosum is a massive curved commissure that interconnects corresponding areas of the two cerebral hemispheres so that these areas may function in a coordinated manner.

item.label: Rostrum
item.name: Rostrum
item.description: The rostrum of the corpus callosum is a thin band of nerve fibers beneath the genu containing commissural fibers interconnecting the orbital cortices.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu
item.description: The genu is the sharp bend in the corpus callosum at it most anterior or rostral aspect.  The commissural fibers within the genu interconnect the frontal lobes.

item.label: Body
item.name: Body
item.description: The body is the main portion of the corpus callosum containing commissural fibers which distribute extensively between the two hemispheres.

item.label: Splenium
item.name: Splenium
item.description: The splenium is the thick and rounded posterior aspect of the corpus callosum.  These commissural axons interconnect the occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Fornix
item.name: Fornix
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily efferents from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus. Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Caudate nucleus
item.name: Caudate nucleus
item.description: The caudate nucleus is the medial portion of the striatum. It consists of a large head that bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle, a body that narrows and curves along the body of the lateral ventricle and a tail that continues through the atrium or trigone of the lateral ventricle and into the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. Principal connections are with the prefrontal and other association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic chiasm
item.name: Optic chiasm
item.description: The optic chiasm is a midline structure that consists of the axons of retinal neurons located in the nasal half of each retina.  These nerve fibers travel first in the optic nerve and then cross in midline of the optic chiasm so that the input from the nasal retina of each eye (temporal visual field) projects to the contralateral optic tract and beyond in the visual pathway. Input from the temporal retina (nasal visual field) does NOT cross in the chiasm but projects through the ipsilateral visual pathway.  This partial crossing of the visual input is essential for binocular vision.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Epithalamus, Pineal gland
item.name: Pineal gland
item.description: The pineal gland is the part of the epithalamus that extends caudally from the area of the habenular nuclei and into the superior cistern, immediately dorsal to the superior colliculi. As an endocrine gland, it secretes melatonin and is involved with circadian rhythms and the sleep-wake cycle.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Tectum
item.name: Tectum
item.description: The tectum is that portion of the midbrain located above the cerebral aqueduct.  It includes the superior and inferior colliculi which are AKA the quadrigeminal bodies.

item.label: Oculomotor nerve
item.name: Oculomotor nerve
item.description: The third or oculomotor cranial nerve provides motor innervation to the ipsilateral medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique and levator palapebrae muscles that move the eye. It also includes parasympathetic fibers that terminate in the ipsilateral ciliary ganglion; post-ganglionic fibers from the ciliary ganglion innervate the constrictors of the pupil and the ciliary muscles.

item.label: Pons
item.name: Pons
item.description: The pons is that portion of the brainstem between the midbrain and medulla. It consists of a basilar or basal portion that contains structures primarily associated with motor control and a tegmental portion that contains cranial nerve nuclei and important sensory tracts. The cerebellum overlies the pons and medulla. The rostral aspect of the fourth ventricle is located on the dorsal surface of the pons. The pons and cerebellum originate embryologically from the metencephalon of the hindbrain.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerebellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Anterior cerebral artery
item.name: Anterior cerebral a
item.description: The anterior cerebral artery is the most anterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it curves around the genu and then superior to the corpus callosum to supply the orbital gyri, medial aspect of the frontal lobe, a portion of the parietal lobe and a narrow band along the most superior region of the lateral aspect of the hemisphere. Since the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule which is responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral lower extremity, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower extremity.

item.label: Pericallosal artery
item.name: Pericallosal artery
item.description: The pericallosal artery is the continuation of the anterior cerebral artery as it arches superiorly and posteriorly over the corpus callosum.  It supplies portions of the medial surface of the hemisphere as well as part of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Callosomarginal artery
item.name: Callosomarginal artery
item.description: The callosomarginal artery is a branch of the anterior cerebral artery that follows along the cingulate sulcus.

item.label: Lateral ventricle
item.name: Lateral ventricle
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Interventricular foramen
item.name: Interventricular foramen
item.description: The interventricular foramen is AKA the foramen of Monro. The paired interventricular foramina are channels for cerebrospinal flow from each lateral ventricle to the third ventricle.

item.label: Third ventricle
item.name: Third ventricle
item.description: The third ventricle is a single, narrow, vertically-oriented portion of the ventricular system.  It is located between the two halves of the thalamus and hypothalamus.

item.label: Cerebral aqueduct
item.name: Cerebral aqueduct
item.description: The cerebral aqueduct is AKA the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.  It is a narrow channel within the midbrain through which cerebrospinal fluid flows from the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.

item.label: Fourth ventricle
item.name: Fourth ventricle
item.description: The fourth ventricle is a rhomboid-shaped space located superior to the pons and medulla. The roof of the fourth ventricle is formed by the inferior and superior medullary vela plus the cerebellum. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) enters the fourth ventricle from the third ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct. CSF exits the fourth ventricle into the subarachnoid space via the medial foramen of Magendie, located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, and the two lateral foramina of Luschka, located at the most lateral aspect of the fourth ventricle, i.e. in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle, bilaterally.  The choroid plexus is located in the roof of the fourth ventricle, beneath the inferior medullary velum.  The choroid plexus extends outside of the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka, where it can be visualized in the subarachnoid space.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.
